He notes that an inscription on the last page indicates that the manuscript was donated by Hadji Ab-Bassim to the school (possibly the school of Bekikhan in the city of Jazir). This leaf of notes is on file in the Library.

physical_description: Extent: 214 leaves : paper ; 322 x 215 (235 x 150) mm bound to 315 x 220 mm.
note: Copy of a poem and vocabulary sheet laid in. Calligraphic design in black ink and colored sketch of a tree in orange and yellow drawn into the back inside cover. Sketches of swords on back flyleaf.

Letter dated 13 December 1907 from Dr. S.A. Sterrett Metheny to Dr. Morris Jastrow, Jr. was laid into the manuscript. Metheny indicates that the manuscript had been bought about twenty years earlier by Rev. Henry Easson, a Presbyterian missionary, from a Turkish soldier who said he had captured it in the house of a sheikh during a punitive expedition to the Ansyri mountains east of...
Seal of Solomon written out (p. 329) and also a stamp with the name Sulaymā̄n appear in several places throughout (p. 1, 156, 329, for example).

physical_description: Extent: 123 leaves : parchment, ill. ; 131 x 98 (105 x 70) mm. bound to 141 x 113 mm.
note: Ms. codex.

Begins imperfectly. Original foliation in rubricated Roman numerals appears on the verso side of fols. 1-24 and 56-109. The numerals have been trimmed in rebinding, which may explain the absence of original foliation for fols. 25-55 and 110-122. The remnants of the original foliation indicate that a quire of 8 leaves preceded the text as it exists today.
A note on fol. 122v in Italian is dated 1600.
Music: Contains musical notation.
Former shelfmark: MSS Bd. Rare BX C36 A637
Related shelfmark: MS B.21 (De Ricci)

physical_description: Extent: 121 leaves : parchment, ill. ; 226 x 170 (164 x 117) mm. bound to 236 x 180 mm.
note: Composite ms. codex.

Fols. 1-72 are numbered (in medieval Arabic numerals) to correspond with the quodlibetal question that appears on that folio; many of these numerals, which appear in the upper right corner of the recto side, have been mutilated by trimming. The absence of such numeration from fols. 73-90 may be due to trimming.
Fol. 104 has been torn, with the loss of some text.
Accompanying materials: three leaves of Latin transcription in modern cursive hands.
Former shelfmark: MSS Bd. Rare BX J17
Related shelfmark: MS B.11 (De Ricci)
The present manuscript was used by Eelcko Ypma in his edition of the Disputatio Quarta of James of Viterbo (1975), but not in his editions of the earlier books.

physical_description: Extent: 1 v. (395 leaves) : col. ill. ; 30 cm.
Extent: 147 leaves : parchment ; 190 x 130 (125-135 x 60-65) mm. bound to 199 x 137 mm.
note: Ms. codex.
The first 36 folios contain numerous brief glosses in the margins (mostly of place-names that occur in the text).
Folios 105 and 112 have been incorrectly bound, and the modern foliation has taken the error into account. Thus, the folios are numbered: 1-104, 106-111, 105, 113-120, 112, 121-147.
Many of the folios are palimpsest; the earlier script appears to be a 14th or 15th century cursive, and may be written in a vernacular, possibly Portugese.

Several mutilated folios which are missing marginal strips of parchment have been repaired with tissue. The last two folios (both blank) have been pasted together, apparently to repair the mutilation of the second.

Accompanying materials: Note in blue ink in a modern hand, tipped into the front flyleaves, indicating the contents of the codex. Typed note on index card which claims Portugese origin for the codex and suggests that it "very probably belonged to one of the old navigators" (but no reasons for these suppositions are given).
Former shelfmark: MSS Bd. Rare P P72 N2
Related shelfmark: MS B.6 (De Ricci)

physical_description: Extent: 135 leaves : paper ; 206 x 154 (137-165 x 95-120) mm. bound to 216 x 165 mm.
note: Ms. codex.

The text of Eutropius corresponds to pp. 6-182 of Droysen's edition in the Monumenta Germaniae Historica, vol. 2 (1879); it follows the version of Paul the Deacon, which appears in Droyen's apparatus. Although the version in Misc. Bd. Ms. 131 includes Paul the Deacon's summary of Roman prehistory ("Primus in Italia...", pp. 6-7), it omits Paul's additions to Eutropius (Books 11-16...
The bottom margin of fol. 1 has been cut away.

A note in pencil by George Lincoln Burr draws attention to the date "1556 Maij diei 8" which accompanies Antonius Grotta's "Carmen extemporaneum" (consisting of a mere couplet) on fol. 76r. It should be observed that Antonius's hand differs from the rest of the manuscript (apart from the alphabet on f. 78r), and that his writing appears in a blank space within a larger text. Hence...
Accompanying materials: Partial transcription of the "Compendium rethorice" (f. 81r) in a modern hand, on a single sheet inserted in the back of the codex.
Former shelfmark: MSS Bd. Rare P E91
Related shelfmark: MS B.8 (De Ricci)

physical_description: Extent: 220 leaves : parchment ; 183 x 132 (125 x 90) mm. bound to 193 x 137 mm.
note: Ms. codex.

There are numerous marginal annotations in various hands from the 13th to the 16th centuries, including corrections to the text and headings (headings also appear as rubrications set within the body of the text). Corrections to the text are in a near-contemporary hand.

Early foliation is in Roman numerals for ff. 1-121 (although most of the numerals before f. 49 have been lost in trimming); and in Arabic numerals, in a medieval hand, for ff. 92, 122-220. Due to misnumbering, the medieval foliation of ff. 93-116 and 122-220 is inaccurate.
Fol. 220r contains an index of references to the city of Arles, dated 1576. On f. 220v a similarly late hand has added notes which are partly erased or crossed out.
Former shelfmark: MSS Bd. Rare D G38
Related shelfmark: MSS. B 6000 (Faye and Bond)

physical_description: Extent: 134 leaves : paper (2 leaves parchment) ; 218 x 145 (138 x 85) mm. bound to 222 x 160 mm.
note: Ms. codex.

The first four leaves are not foliated. Modern pencilled foliation appears at the bottom center of the recto side of each leaf; earlier foliation in ink, often at variance with the modern, appears at the bottom right.
The bifolium that constitutes ff. 1 and 10 is parchment; all the other leaves are paper.

physical_description: Extent: 160 leaves : parchment ; 210 x 145 (162 x 98) mm. bound to 219 x 159 mm.
note: Ms. codex.

The manuscript begins and ends imperfectly. Quires are missing after ff. 60, 84, and 120, and some of the existing quires are bound in the incorrect order. See the note by Dr. Eric Millar tipped into the first flyleaf, and the annotations penciled into the manuscript itself by a modern hand.

Accompanying Materials: Description of the manuscript in a modern hand on lined paper tipped into the recto side of the first flyleaf; note in a different modern hand pasted onto the verso of the rear flyleaf, which identifies the author of the description (and of the table of contents that follows) as Dr. Eric Millar; table of contents glued to the rear pastedown.
Former shelfmark: MSS Bd. Rare BX S47

physical_description: Extent: 30 leaves : paper, ill. ; 219 x 146 (167 x 112) mm., unbound.
note: Ms. gatherings.

This manuscript is related to Misc. Bd. Mss. 12 and 146. All three are unbound, written on paper of nearly identical dimensions and in the same script, and all three were acquired together from the same source.
The date "1438" appears on fol. 16r in the text, and is repeated in the outer margin in ink by a 19th-century hand.
Fol. 11 is torn, so that text on 11r and half of a full-page table on 11v have been lost.
A slip of paper has been inserted to add a table between fols. 13v and 14r; the other half of the slip, appearing between fols. 21v and 22r, is blank.

Accompanying materials: Loose paper cover in which the manuscript was once stored, with the title "Computus Cirometralis [1438.]" in the hand of George Lincoln Burr; inside the cover is a note by Burr indicating provenance and other details about the manuscript.
Former shelfmark: MSS Bd. Rare P A78
Related shelfmark: MS B.53 (De Ricci)

physical_description: Extent: 45 leaves (originally 48, but 3 leaves have been lost) : parchment ; 227 x 162 (175 x 115) mm. bound to 230 x 164 mm.
note: Ms. codex.

The central bifolium of the first quire (ff. 4-5) has been lost, so the codex lacks the text for Rhetorica ad Herennium 1.9.16-1.14.24 (i.e., "parum fuisse...recte factum"; pp. 28.4-44.2 in Harry Caplan's edition). A note in a modern hand on f. 3v observes the hiatus, and the foliation takes into account the absence of ff. 4-5.
Fols. 1-3 were mutilated and subsequently repaired with parchment; the affected text was skillfully restored in a neat humanistic hand of the 15th century.

The folios of the first quire were once incorrectly bound, but were rebound ca. 1986 and are now set in the correct order. The modern notes in pencil on ff. 1v, 7v, and 8v which were intended to guide the reader through the confusion of the misbound folios are now obsolete.
The manuscript is heavily glossed throughout in a 14th-century Gothic cursive hand (both interlinear and marginal glosses).
Annotations include outlines of the subject-matter in schematic diagrams, which appear in some of the bottom margins.
Former shelfmark: MSS Bd. Rare P R47
Related shelfmark: MS B.28 (De Ricci)
subject_recorded: Cicero, Marcus Tullius--Spurious and doubtful works

shelfmark: Eugene, OR, Special Collections and University Archives, University of Oregon, MS 040.
physical_description: Extent: 119 leaves : paper ; 220 x 288 mm. bound to 225 x 300 mm.
note: Manuscript codex.
Title devised by cataloger.
Collation (Cicero): 50 leaves, Quires of 10 + 2 front flyleaves. No page headings, numbers, signatures. Catchwords in middle lower margin at end of quires.
Collation (Justinus): 69 leaves, quires of 10 except last of 9. Catchwords in middle lower margin at end of quires. No page headings, numbers, signatures.
Layout (Cicero): Double columns of 44-45 lines each. Little ruling, done in lead or graphite. Blank spaces for initial letters. Paper watermarked.
Layout (Justinus): 2. Lightly ruled, single column, 40-43 lines per page. Paragraphs separated by line space and marginal headings. Blank spaces for initial letters.
Paper: the two manuscripts use different paper stocks, with different watermarks. In the Justinus manuscript, there is a shears watermark on f. 69.

"Justinus the historian [was] of unknown date, but not later than 300 or 400 AD. His work is taken from the Historiae Philippicae of Progus Pompeius...writing the history of Macedonian monarchy....Justin's work is not so much an abridgment as a selection of those parts [of Trogus' history] which seemed to him most worthy of being generally known"--Edward Sandford Burgess notes.
Includes two pages of written notes by Edward Sandford Burgess on Justinus and his text, and notes on the veneration of Cicero's texts by later scholars.

The Ricketts fragment was written within a century of Bede's life and it was formerly ascribed to England, s. VIII (Colgrave and Mynors 1969; Gneuss 1981). Superb example of Anglo-Saxon/Insular minuscule. The other half of the Lilly leaf is in the Universitätsund Landesbibliotek, Düsseldorf, K1:B216. The Düsseldorf half was a fragment recovered from the bindings of early printed...
Latin.

Text is from near the end of Bede's Historical Ecclesiastica book V, chapter 13. This passage is part of the account of a man who lies dying and has a vision of an angel and a devil, each carrying books recording the man's good deeds and his sins, one volume bound in white and the other in black. As such it is a rare literary reference to books and bookbindings in early...

L. Ricketts, and acquired by the Lilly Library with the Ricketts Collection in 1961.

Much of the Olcott colletion is now in Columbia University Library. Tombstone was inscribed c.II and taken down and re-incised on the verso in the third or fouth century. The stencilled "175" in red may be earlier than Olcott's acquisition. Kept in a fawn cloth case.
Latin.

Translation: "To the immortal shades, Marcus Ulpius Julianus made this for his son Ulpius Portensi." Ulpius was the family name of Trajan (emperor 98-117 A.D.) and afterwards became a common personal name in his honour. 'Portensi' is probably Portus 'Porto' in modern Italian, the harbour near Rome at the mouth of the Tiber, founded in the first century.

Translation: "To the immortal shades, Nene made this for her well-desrving husband Antiochus; he lived 65 years." Nene is an unusual name, not apparently attested elsewhere in ancient Rome but known in the eastern Mediterranean.
associated_name_recorded: Found and acquired probably in the region of Rome by George N. Olcott (1869-1912), American classicist in Rome; given by his widow to the American Academy in Rome by 1927; sold by the Academy through B. l. Ullman to George A. Poole in 1951, and acquired by the Lilly Library with the Poole Collection in 1958.

note: Stained and wormed. Apparently part of the miscellaneous leaves cut from books in the new municipal library in Arras in 1810. It is the leaf now missing between f.2 and f.3 of Arras, Blbliothèque municpale, ms 1079 (Catalogue general IV, 1872, pp. 104-5, no. 235), which was listed at St-Vaast by 1628, when it was A.148 in the library catalogue. It is almost certainly the oldest...
The commentary written in the inner columns is in a Carolingian minuscule, the biblical lemmata in the outer columns in uncial.
Latin.

The present leaf, with commentary on the Song of Songs 1:8 to 2:4, corresponds to Migne PL 100:644-46. Only six other copies are recorded of Alcuin's compendium on the Song of Songs (Sharpe 1997, p. 37).
associated_name_recorded: The Abbey of St-Vaast in Arras; Sir Thomas Phillips (1792-1872), part of his MS 22229; from the collection of specimen leaves formed by Messrs. W.H. Robinson, who bought the residue of the Phillips Library in 1945-46, sold by them to George A. Poole in 1947, and acquired by the Lilly Library with the Poole Collection in 1958.

note: By the fifteenth century the manuscript had apparently lost a leaf or two at the beginning, and the stained and darkened f. 1r here was the first to survive. Ferrari and Rouse (1991, p. 93) compare the script with Monza, Biblioteca capitolare c. 5/65, written in Monza.
Latin.

Extracts from Bede's Homiliae 1:3 (Gregoire 1966, p. 78, no. 11; Hurst 1960, pp. 14-15, lines 9-136). The cryptic price ‘£bee.e.e’ on his bookplate is Henry Yates Thompson's (1838-1928) purchase cost, using his code word ‘bryanstone’, whereby ‘a’ = 1, ‘r’ = 2, ‘y’ = 3, and so on; this manuscript therefore cost him £100.

Some pages very rubbed. The original patron of the manuscript is represented by the young man in red robes, trimmed in gold, kneeling before King David in the opening initial on fol. 7r. Groupings of the O.T. books of the bible into Legal, Historical, Sapiential, Prophetic; then the N.T. in the Gospels, the Catholic Epistles, the Pauline Epistles (this list carried forward by a tie mark, "f," from the lower verso to the recto).

This text also in Vienna, Osterreichische Nationalbibliothek, Cod. 505, ff. 3-11v, containing the series of O.T. patriarchs from Adam to Christ. Each genealogical line follows a specific colored line: red, blue, light purple and so on.
